subsection.title: Integration by parts
subsection.p:
The fundamental theorem of calculus tells us that it is very easy to integrate a derivative. In particular, we know that
\int \diff{}{x}\left( F(x) \right) \dee{x} &= F(x)+C
We can exploit this in order to develop another rule for integration in particular a rule to help us integrate products of simpler function such as
\int x e^x \dee{x}
In so doing we will arrive at a method called integration by parts.

To do this we start with the product rule and integrate. Recall that the product rule says
\diff{}{x} u(x)v(x) = u'(x)\,v(x)+u(x)\,v'(x)
Integrating this gives
\int \big[u'(x)\,v(x)+u(x)\,v'(x)\big]\dee{x} &=\big[\text{a function whose derivative is $u'v+uv'$}\big] + C
&=u(x)v(x) +C
Now this, by itself, is not terribly useful. In order to apply it we need to have a function whose integrand is a sum of products that is in exactly this form u'(x)v(x) + u(x)v'(x). This is far too specialised.
Let us do a simple example before explaining this more generally.

ul.li: Now set u(x)=x and v'(x)=e^x. How did we know how to make this choice? We will explain some strategies later. For now, let us just accept this choice and keep going.
In order to use the formula we need to know u'(x) and v(x). In this case it is quite straightforward: u'(x)=1 and v(x)=e^x.

Plug everything into the formula:
\int x e^x \dee{x} &= x e^x - \int e^x \dee{x}
So our original more difficult integral has been turned into a question of computing an easy one.
&= x e^x - e^x +C

subsection.p: The process we have used in the above example is called integration by parts. When our integrand is a product we try to write it as u(x) v'(x) we need to choose one factor to be u(x) and the other to be v'(x). We then compute u'(x) and v(x) and then apply the following theorem:

statement.p:
The corresponding statement for definite integrals is
\int_a^b u(x)\,v'(x)\dee{x} = u(b)\,v(b)-u(a)\,v(a)-\int_a^b v(x)\,u'(x)\dee{x}

subsection.p:
Integration by parts is not as easy to apply as the product rule for derivatives. This is because it relies on us
judiciously choosing u(x) and v'(x), then
computing u'(x) and v(x) which requires us to antidifferentiate v'(x), and finally
that the integral \int u'(x) v(x)\dee{x} is easier than the integral we started with.

In most applications (but not all) our integrand will be a product of two factors so we have two choices for u(x) and v'(x). Typically one of these choices will be good (in that it results in a simpler integral) while the other will be bad (we cannot antidifferentiate our choice of v'(x) or the resulting integral is harder). Let us illustrate what we mean by returning to our previous example.

example.title: \int xe^x \dee{x} again
example.p:
Our integrand is the product of two factors
x && \text{and} && e^x
This gives us two obvious choices of u and v':
u(x)&=x & v'(x)&=e^x
\text{ or}
u(x)&=e^x & v'(x)&=x
We should explore both choices:
If take u(x)=x and v'(x)=e^x. We then quickly compute
u'(x)&=1 &\text{and} && v(x)=e^x
which means we will need to integrate (in the right-hand side of the integration by parts formula)
\int u'(x) v(x) \dee{x} &= \int 1 \cdot e^x \dee{x}
which looks straightforward. This is a good indication that this is the right choice of u(x) and v'(x).
But before we do that, we should also explore the other choice, namely u(x)=e^x and v'(x)=x. This implies that
u'(x)&= e^x &\text{and}&& v(x)&= \frac{1}{2}x^2
which means we need to integrate
\int u'(x) v(x) \dee{x} &= \int \frac{1}{2}x^2 \cdot e^x \dee{x}.
This is at least as hard as the integral we started with. Hence we should try the first choice.
With our choice made, we integrate by parts to get
\int xe^x \dee{x} &= xe^x - \int e^x \dee{x}
&= xe^x - e^x +C.
The above reasoning is a very typical workflow when using integration by parts.

subsection.p:
Integration by parts is often used
to eliminate factors of x from an integrand like xe^x by using that \diff{}{x}x=1 and
to eliminate a \log x from an integrand by using that \diff{}{x}\log x=\frac{1}{x} and
to eliminate inverse trig functions, like \arctan x, from an integrand by using that, for example, \diff{}{x}\arctan x=\frac{1}{1+x^2}.

li.p:
Again we have a product of two factors giving us two possible choices.
If we choose u(x)=x and v'(x)=\sin x, then we get
u'(x) &=1 &\text{and} && v(x) &= -\cos x
which is looking promising.
On the other hand if we choose u(x)=\sin x and v'(x)=x, then we have
u'(x)&=\cos x &\text{and} && v(x) &= \frac{1}{2}x^2
which is looking worse we'd need to integrate \int \frac{1}{2}x^2 \cos x \dee{x}.

ul.li:
Again we can check our answer by differentiating:
\diff{}{x}\left( -x\cos x + \sin x + C \right) &= -\cos x + x\sin x + \cos x + 0
&= x \sin x \checkmark

example.p: Once we have practised this a bit we do not really need to write as much. Let us solve it again, but showing only what we need to.

ul.li: We use integration by parts to solve the integral.

example.title: \int x\sin x\dee{x} yet again

subsection.p: We can also use integration by parts to eliminate higher powers of x. We just need to apply the method more than once.

Now let us look at integrands containing logarithms. We don't know the antiderivative of \log x, but we can eliminate \log x from an integrand by using integration by parts with u=\log x. Remember \log x = \log_e x = \ln x.

li.p:
We have two choices for u and \dee{v}.
Set u=x and \dee{v}=\log x\dee{x}. This gives \dee{u}=\dee{x} but v is hard to compute we haven't done it yet We will soon.. Before we go further along this path, we should look to see what happens with the other choice.
Set u=\log x and \dee{v}=x\dee{x}. This gives \dee{u}=\frac{1}{x}\dee{x} and v=\frac{1}{2}x^2, and we have to integrate
\int v\, \dee{u} &= \int \frac{1}{x} \cdot \frac{1}{2}x^2 \dee{x}
which is easy.

ul.li:
We can check our answer quickly:
\diff{}{x} \Big(\frac{x^2}{2} \ln x -\frac{x^2}{4} +C\Big) &= x\,\ln x + \frac{x^2}{2}\,\frac{1}{x} -\frac{x}{2}+0 =x\,\ln x

In the previous example we saw that we could remove the factor \log x by setting u=\log x and using integration by parts. Let us try repeating this. When we make this choice, we are then forced to take \dee{v}=\dee{x} that is we choose v'(x)=1. Once we have made this sneaky move everything follows quite directly.

As always, it is a good idea to check our result by verifying that the derivative of the answer really is the integrand.
\diff{}{x} \big(x\ln x-x +C\big) &= \ln x + x\,\frac{1}{x} -1+0 =\ln x

subsection.p: The same method works almost exactly to compute the antiderivatives of \arcsin(x) and \arctan(x):

example.title: \int \arctan(x)\dee{x} and \int \arcsin(x)\dee{x}
example.p: Compute the antiderivatives of the inverse sine and inverse tangent functions.

ul.li: Again neither of these integrands are products, but that is no impediment. In both cases we set \dee{v}=\dee{x} (ie v'(x)=1) and choose v(x)=x.
Both can be checked quite quickly by differentiating but we leave that as an exercise for the reader.

subsection.p: There are many other examples we could do, but we'll finish with a tricky one.

example.p:
Solution: Let us attempt this one a little naively and then we'll come back and do it more carefully (and successfully).
We can choose either u=e^x, \dee{v}=\sin x\dee{x} or the other way around.
Let u=e^x, \dee{v}=\sin x\dee{x}. Then \dee{u}=e^x\dee{x} and v=-\cos x. This gives
\int e^x \sin x &= -e^x\cos x + \int e^x \cos x \dee{x}
So we are left with an integrand that is very similar to the one we started with. What about the other choice?
Let u=\sin x, \dee{v}=e^x\dee{x}. Then \dee{u}=\cos x\dee{x} and v= e^x. This gives
\int e^x \sin x &= e^x\sin x - \int e^x \cos x \dee{x}
So we are again left with an integrand that is very similar to the one we started with.
How do we proceed? It turns out to be easier if you do both \int e^x\sin x\dee{x} and \int e^x \cos x\dee{x} simultaneously. We do so in the next example.

example.title: \int_a^b e^x\sin x\dee{x} and \int_a^b e^x\cos x\dee{x}

ul.li:
So summarising, we have
I_1&=\Big[-e^x\cos x\Big]_a^b +I_2 & I_2&=\Big[e^x\sin x\Big]_a^b -I_1

So now, substitute the expression for I_2 from the second equation into the first equation to get
I_1 &=\Big[-e^x\cos x +e^x\sin x\Big]_a^b -I_1
&\hskip0.5in \text{which implies}\qquad I_1=\frac{1}{2}\Big[e^x\big(\sin x-\cos x\big)\Big]_a^b
If we substitute the other way around we get
I_2 &=\Big[e^x\sin x +e^x\cos x\Big]_a^b -I_2
&\hskip0.5in \text{which implies}\qquad I_2=\frac{1}{2}\Big[e^x\big(\sin x+\cos x\big)\Big]_a^b
That is,
\int_a^b e^x\sin x\dee{x}&= \frac{1}{2}\Big[e^x\big(\sin x-\cos x\big)\Big]_a^b
\int_a^b e^x\cos x\dee{x}&= \frac{1}{2}\Big[e^x\big(\sin x+\cos x\big)\Big]_a^b

This also says, for example, that \frac{1}{2}e^x\big(\sin x-\cos x\big) is an antiderivative of e^x\sin x so that
\int e^x\sin x\dee{x}=\frac{1}{2}e^x\big(\sin x-\cos x\big)+C

Note that we can always check whether or not this is correct. It is correct if and only if the derivative of the right hand side is e^x\sin x. Here goes. By the product rule
&=\diff{}{x}\Big[\frac{1}{2}e^x\big(\sin x-\cos x\big)+C\Big]
&=\frac{1}{2}\Big[e^x\big(\sin x-\cos x\big)+e^x\big(\cos x+\sin x\big)\Big] =e^x\sin x
which is the desired derivative.

There is another way to find \int e^x\sin x\dee{x} and \int e^x\cos x\dee{x} that, in contrast to the above computations, doesn't involve any trickery. But it does require the use of complex numbers and so is beyond the scope of this course. The secret is to use that \sin x =\frac{e^{ix}-e^{-ix}}{2i} and \cos x =\frac{e^{ix}+e^{-ix}}{2}, where i is the square root of -1 of the complex number system. See Example .
